message_1:
Calculate the standard electrode potential of the following cell: 

Zn(s) | Zn2+(aq) || Cu2+(aq) | Cu(s) 

Given: Eº(Zn2+(aq)/Zn(s)) = -0.76 V and Eº(Cu2+(aq)/Cu(s)) = +0.34 V.
message_2:
To calculate the standard electrode potential of the given cell, we can use the Nernst equation. However, since we are dealing with standard conditions, the equation simplifies to:

Eº(cell) = Eº(cathode) - Eº(anode)

In this cell, the Zn(s) | Zn2+(aq) half-cell acts as the anode (oxidation) and the Cu2+(aq) | Cu(s) half-cell acts as the cathode (reduction). We are given the standard electrode potentials for both half-cells:

Eº(Zn2+(aq)/Zn(s)) = -0.76 V (anode)
Eº(Cu2+(aq)/Cu(s)) = +0.34 V (cathode)

Now, we can plug these values into the simplified Nernst equation:

Eº(cell) = (+0.34 V) - (-0.76 V)
Eº(cell) = +0.34 V + 0.76 V
Eº(cell) = +1.10 V

The standard electrode potential of the given cell is +1.10 V.
